comments.commentBody: What safety measures are in place in US nuclear reactors that make them safer, more dangerous, or the same as the Fukushima Daiichi reactors?  It seems as if there were insufficient plans in place for a catastrophe such as the earthquake/tsunami that struck Northern Japan.  How can such a crisis regarding the reactors be avoided in other nuclear facilities around the world?

I desperately hope that when the imminent crisis has passed, these 50 are recognized as the heroes that they are and that they AND their families are cared for by the Japanese government and its citizens well into their old age, should they live to see it.  They should by all means be recognized with medals and words, but these will be meaningless unless they are also assured the best healthcare options available, and unless their families' financial states are secured after they are no longer able to work.  My heart goes out to them.

Never in a big disaster is so much owed by so many to so few. It is far too much to ask the 50 people to bear all the risk at the plant. A rotating system from a large pool of workers should be adopted so that each participant will get a much less amount of exposure.
The sacrifice they are making for the good of society is heart-rending. Bless them and keep them.
Churchill's "Never...was so much owed by so many to so few" comes to mind.

With these workers and their exposure to radiation, it got me curious if there is anything that they could take that would help them survive the exposure to the reactors. I found this website

http://www.rifeenergymedicine.com...

I wonder if there is any protocol in place for the workers to take any of these supplements.
It seems one of the things the NIH and like entities should do is to find or develop either medicines or test supplements that will protect people from the hazards of radiation.. Something more than Potassium Iodide.
So we're down to 50 guys with fire hoses. Unbelievable.

What courage, unimaginable selflessness, and self sacrifice these 50 heroes have!  To put their lives at risk  to save their fellow citizens and all humankind is the greatest expression of love there is.  What character of heart!  The world needs to honor these 50 workers and never forget them. And, we all pray that they will live to see a brighter day.

It's just been reported that these workers have stopped work at the plant for now. They didn't cause this disaster. Who in the world has the right to ask them to sacrifice their health and their life for this (probably) lost cause? What did the young "volunteer" soldiers at Chernobyl get for their sacrifice? Basically this: illness, unemployment and a life of suffering (oh, and a medal or something like that). Why do the "little people" always have to pay for the mistakes of the rich and powerful? Enough is enough. There are catastrophes taking place right now in Japan and Libya: where is the world leadership? MIA (Obama: what a disappointment). The only one who seems to be taking some kind of decisive action is Frau Merkel. The French at least recognized the Libyan resistance (of course they don't want to hear anything about nuclear power). All of this is quite worrisome.
Think of these people next time the wealthy try to crush "greedy workers."

I'm completely exasperated with all the conflicting reports. Its quite clear that Tokyo Electric is not telling the truth. We need a team of international experts to be sent there to assess the situation.

A similar situation occurred almost 25 years ago at Chernobyl. More than 10 workers sacrificied their lives (literally) to prevent even worse disaster over there and died a painful death a few weeks later.

That is what heroism is all about but it is very sad that inadequacies of technology or irresponsible operators (in the case of Chernobyl) can cause so many deaths in these 'technological' days.

All what we can do is to wish them them luck and those of us who pray, pray for them. At some point their names should we widely publicized and their families receive a special care.

Technology always required human 'sacrifice' and, apparently, nothing much has changed since the beginning of the industrial age.

Come on guys.  There were hundreds of Americans who dedicated themselves and faced the hazards at the 9/11 site.  Don't you remember.  They have been crawling around begging for help with the many infirmities from their work at the site, frequently life threatening.  And, our Congress ( that is the Republicans in our Congress) voted their benefits completely down this year, until they begged some more and got a deal for a portion of what they needed.

"It wouldn't be hard to find 50 workers in the US to handle a crisis under conditions similar to those in the Japanese plan".

Agree, but there wouldn't be a Wall Street banker within a hundred miles. They'd be to busy "hedging' on the outcomes
"Thousands of tons" of radioactive material sounds a bit too much... I don't think there's any need to exaggerate facts to make it understandable that the guys there have true merit.

Who knew courage had a virtue of excess?

I think we should avoid crass generalizations like that the Japanese are taught to sacrifice for the group. I'm not sure how we can even make sense of that claim--they have advertising and billboards and private property just like we do. Maybe Japanese society is more group-oriented than American society--although even most of the substantial claims in that regard do not account for very natural changes in Japanese society as the war generation and those that immediately followed it are replaced by younger workers and consumers. But it might be a condition of almost all societies, or of life in general, to prize one's individual interests over group interest. Doing so less than twenty-first century Americans hardly suggests Japan goes far enough as to tilt the balance towards the group.

In any case, these workers should be commended for their excellence, not for their country's.

Where is the truth in all of this disaster?
Japanese authorities and the power company, Tokyo Electric, are doing their best to mask the seriousness of this tragedy. They are only concerned with the dollar losses forecasted and to minimize the impact on their image.
Japanese people are a proud people, but everything has a limit. Soon we will be reading about the survivors in despair committing hara-kiri. They did it by the score after the defeat of WWII.
Is anyone asking about the liability of GE, the designers/builders of the power plants now in question?

My heart goes out to these brave, brave men who are willing to sacrifice their lives so that others may be spared.  I still remember the pictures of all those nameless, faceless men working in the rubble of Chernobyl battling to stop a meltdown, knowing that they will probably not survive their ordeal.  From all I've read, death from radiation sickness is a horrible, painful process.  May the kami bless them.

All homage to these brave men -- no question about this.  Yet, shouldn't there be more workers trading off so that the exposures can remain lower and the workers can receive appropriate rest?  Also, a tremendous battle is being waged tactically by these courageous few -- but who is attacking the problem strategically, so that meltdown can be avoided over the longer term.  The facilities are clearly severely damaged -- and the fires which break out release large amounts of radiation -- increasing the human risks yet further.  That is to say, we need progress of a fundamental, structural kind that no one has yet been able to make.  It is my understanding that the CEO of Tesco initially proposed evacuating all of the workers, every last one, which would have led to meltdown of several reactors in short order.  Only Prime Minister Kan's objection ("Retreat is unthinkable!") led to these fifty workers being left to fight this formidable fight.  However, now that the disaster has been assessed as a level 6 out of 7, and expected to worsen, we must speak a word about efficacy and sovereignty.  While the Japanese have suffered two enormous natural disasters with more grace and diligence than the world has witnessed in a very long time -- they clearly need active support from the international community.  If an environmental disaster is unfolding which will affect the entire planet, and this one will, then all of the major nations need to bring their experts to the table to solve the problem.  And I'm not talking about consulting, I'm talking about decision-making and chain of command.  Mr. Obama, I'm calling your name.  Surely we have the resources and the expertise to think outside the box regarding solutions to this unfolding catastrophe.  Prime Minister Kan needs to accept top-level assistance immediately.  50 workers with radiation sickness and a world with multiple reactors melting down is not a courageous victory -- either for Japan or for the planet.  It's well past time that all nations bring their best resources and minds to bear on this one in the most forceful of ways.  I mean now.

My friend from Tokyo was supposed to visit me next week. Unfortunately, the tsunami hit her hometown, Fukushima.Her family is okay though.  Her father works at the nuclear power plant in the area and her brother is a rescue worker. Both are working to dampen the crisis and sacrificing their lives for the country.

I pray for them through my tears. I hope that history remembers them.

http://www.nycsinglemom.com

A country know for advanced robotics, why cant they deploy robots everywhere especially to water??. with 3D vision and other sensing technologies that are at our disposable, this should have been an option instead of endangering human lives.Isnt what the robots are for?

Samurai Spirit in action, no doubt.

Can't quit because many others will die & can't leave because they're radioactive.

To soldier on, knowing both the cause & their lives are lost, is very noble.

NPR On Point reported tonight that although thyroid cancer occurred in 7,000 children after the Chernobyl catastrophy, there were not a higher rate of other cancers. I believe that we do not know the consequences of a reactor accident. The Sovietunion hid the news for the people. High radioactivity was first discovered 2 days after the accident at the Swedish nuclear plant Forsmark 1,100 km away. People are still forbidden to live in a vast area around Chernobyl, although some people returned. In 2003 a physician in Kiev, Ucraine, told me that the cancer data were still not known. The radioactivity in the Kiev river, where the children were swimming, was still high but unknown to the population. I am a physician and I have never seen so many emaciated peopleon the streets, who looked seriously ill and had wide spread strange skin disorders and scars, which I believe were caused by the radioactivity.
Lisbeth Nordstrom-Lerner, M.D.
True hero's...Truer Grit
